paragraphs.subtitle: Charlottesville, VA; liz@lizschley.org
paragraphs.text: Experienced back end web developer who loves to program. For the past year, Python has been my main language, but for the prior six and a half years worked mostly with Ruby on Rails, with some Javascript and PHP. Still earlier, Java was my main language. Worked for four years with AWS (S3, EC2, SNS, SQS, Aurora & Cloudfront) and over ten years with relational databases, most recently Postgres and mySql.

paragraphs.subtitle: Portfolio: Inquiries and Observations Site
paragraphs.text:
Web Developer: Developed lizschley.com in order to learn Python, have a personal site for study and a platform for trying out new ideas and technologies. The content management decisions are based on the easiest way for me to add data and to learn. For further information see the Demo page. (2020 - Current)

Technologies: Python, Django, Postgres, SCSS, HTML, Javascript, AWS: EC2, S3, RDS, Cloudfront

paragraphs.subtitle: CoConstruct, LLC
paragraphs.text:
QA Automation Engineer: Worked with devops quality engineers to develop a world class Azure Pipeline by setting up a UI testing framework and many tests that covered vital functionality, using data driven, screen scraping and object oriented approaches and caching for speed and efficiency. (2019 - 2020 (5 months))

Technologies: Python, Pytest, Selenium, Azure, SQL Server

paragraphs.subtitle: Teachstone Training, LLC
paragraphs.text:
Backend Web Developer: Worked with developers, devops, product management, QA, content and customer service to create and maintain a web application to help teachers improve their interactions with their students. The system interfaced with third party services, including BigCommerce, FedEx and Moodle, and in-house mobile applications and multiple applications using both restful and other Rails and PHP interfaces. Played a large role in developing a single signon system for both third party and in-house systems. Wrote many unit and integration tests. (2013 - 2019)

Technologies: Rspec, Ruby, Rails, PHP, MySQL, New Relic, AWS

paragraphs.subtitle: Medical Automation Systems (Abbott)
paragraphs.text:
Project Manager: Helped lead many projects through conception to release, following FDA compliant software development practices, including test plan approval, risk management and problem solving strategies. (2007 - 2012)

Technologies: Rspec, Ruby, Rails, PHP, MySQL, New Relic, AWS

paragraphs.subtitle: LexisNexis
paragraphs.text:
Senior Software Engineer: Worked as technical lead and developer for a customer-facing eCommerce web-site that interfaced with multiple order fulfillment and financial back-end systems. Responsible for both release and test plans, timely releases, unit and integration testing and project management. Designed and wrote an object-oriented Java web service as one of several middle-ware strategies. (1999 - 2007)

Technologies: Java web services, ASP, Javascript, XSLT, VB, FE

Computer Programmer: Moved from entry level position to Senior Software Engineer by taking courses, self-study, hard work and excellent results. Worked on timecards, order fulfillment, invoices, pricing and subscription reporting. (1993 - 1999)

Technologies: Java, JS, VB, Oracle, Sybase, SQL Server, Mainframe

paragraphs.subtitle: Education
paragraphs.text:
• Masters of Science - Information Studies, Florida State University: 4.0 GPA
  • BA in English, Old Dominion University
  • Java Certified Java 2 Platform

Extracting, loading and transforming data is basic to programming. As a tech lead for an ecommerce website, I figured out how long each task would take by estimating three phases for each task: import, transform and export. It made sense to the other programmers and because our estimates were accurate, our releases were on time. For this website (Python and Django), I compose and update text using JSON files and VSCode or by loading existing csv files or screen scraping HTML. In the past, I have created PHP plugins, rest interfaces, Java Webservices and have used off the shelf ETL software.

• Implemented an end-point for uploading complex data to a relational database from an end-user supplied spreadsheet. The process updated or created records in at least seven different tables and validated against even more. In order to ensure integrity, created extensive rspec tests, making sure to validate all the business rules. There were few to no bugs, with extensive use an in spite of the fact that the original Jira tickets did not have all the AC criteria spelled out.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, CSV Processing, API, MySql
    Company: Teachstone, Backend Web Developer

• Using a rest API, based on a request sent by a mobile application, extracted data from one of three very different back-end systems: two Ruby on Rails and one Totara. Based on another request, loaded the data sent by the mobile app to the correct backend system.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, Rest API, HTML5, MySQL, Totara, PHP
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• As a Technical Lead for a customer-facing web-site, familiarized myself with various middleware processes that interfaced with multiple backends, situated in three different states: Virgina, New York and Ohio.
    Technologies: Java, Javascript, ASP, Web Services, Intalio and other middleware applications, XML, XSLT, SQL Server, Sybase, IDMS
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Incorporated Totara, an LMS based off of Moodle, into our existing processes by learning how to create and implement Moodle web services. This required mapping our data with information displayed on the Totara web page. Was successful, in spite of the fact that the Totara database fields that I needed to update were often named and fielded in non-intuitive ways.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, Totara, Moodle, PHP, MySQL
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• Conceived and executed strategy for programmatically creating programs, SQL code, and XML definitions by reading data definition files, saving over a month of development time in data archiving project.
    Technologies: Sybase, IDMS, SAS, SQL, Web Services, XML
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Developed and implemented a plan for table-based transformation in data conversion, becoming a natural leader for the project as a result of this initiative.
    Technologies: Java, CSV Processing, SAS, IDMS, Sybase
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Fixed highly inaccurate subscription data used by sales reps without disturbing the production process. This was particularly challenging because there were no matching keys and three fundamental problems with the original extract. Sent SQL updates for over 50% of the records (a logistical problem) and rewrote the extract, so that sales reps had completely accurate information going forward.
    Technologies: SAS, IDMS, Sybase
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Wrote programs in PHP that parsed and analyzed text files for data conversion from Excel and Word to SQL Server, and to aid in DIACAP certification.
    Technologies: PHP, SQL Server, Excel Word, SQL
    Company: Medical Automation Systems (Abbott), Project Manager

• Developed on-line pricing form, extracting and using data from many different data sources, thus saving the company $10,560 per year by saving time for Editorial management team.
    Technologies: SQL Server, Sybase, IDMS, SAS, SQL
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Initiated and led effort to fix problem caused by Windows Security Patch by upgrading MSXML. Implementation required research into IIS security and registry settings and negotiation for a new integration server and both technical and business resources.
    Technologies: Java, JavaScript, XML, XSLT, SQL, ASP, HTML
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Built cross-application monitoring for data syncs, using New Relic Insight custom fields, allowing us to measure the time from one in-house application to another through a third-party application for which we had no access. We created alerts and New Relic dashboards based on the resulting data. As a by-product, the information helped with bug analysis.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, New Relic
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• Instituted logging, log parsing and data analysis to systematically eliminate pre-existing inefficiencies and bugs in the site for which I was in charge.
    Technologies: Java, JavaScript, Excel

• Implemented, as one of my first ruby projects, single sign-on according to complex requirements. As the requirements changed, played a major role in that implementation as well.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, JavaScript, HTML5, Web Server Authentication
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• Automated status reports that read MS Project and produced Excel Reports with four months rolling history, allowing the engineering department to accurately and consistently report progress to the management team.
    Technologies: VBA with MS Project and Excel
    Company: Medical Automation Systems (Abbott)

This past year, I have developed this site, which, as I realized while playing around with |beg|drupal|end|, is a |beg|content-management-system|end| [CMS]. I have also created a small |beg_ref|lizschley_drupaldemosite_on2021040|end_ref|. In addition, I have written many plugins and blocks (in PHP) for |beg|totara|end|, based on |beg|moodle|end|, which although a |beg|learning-management-system|end|, also manages data like a CMS and, like Drupal, is open source and written in PHP. In addition to experience with PHP, Javascript, CSS and HTML, I also have years of experience with Github, CircleCI, Yaml, deploy hooks and other technologies commonly used in Web Development.

What follows is a detailed description of some of my experience with Totara:

• Moodle to Totara Conversion
    Goal: Ensure all existing moodle processes continue to work after the conversion.
    My responsibilities: Preliminary analysis and about half of the programming work (including all of the work described here).
    Totara is based directly on Moodle, so the data could be transferred using standard |beg_ref|oracle_importingexportingmysqldatabases_on20210422|end_ref|. Other work involved both changes to programming code (creating and/or Calling |beg_ref|moodle_doc_localplugins_on20210422|end_ref|) and editing and implementing the release plan.
    • Worked with the devops team
      • Planned additional steps at the correct spot in the release plan
      • Took both testing and production phases into consideration
      • Stayed up late to do perform manual steps and testing at the appropriate stage in the actual production deployment
    • Discovered the need to use a universal primary key to identify users
      • Developed process to use this unique key wherever necessary
      • Figured out how to populate the field for all of the existing users, including students
      • Populated the unique identifier while adding new users
    • Created and/or called PHP Plugins to respond to events initiated in Ruby on Rails
      • Added new students and users with roles to control permissions
      • Updated existing users
      • Enrolled students in courses
      • Changed course enrollment dates
    • Gave the plugins necessary permission, made them discoverable and activated them by creating correctly formatted configuration file

• Created new PHP Plugins to extend the functionality in Totara
    • Created custom fields to control permissions both directly and by assigning and unassigning roles. The values in the custom fields were controlled by events from another application
      • When a user successfully passed a certification test for a given level and age level, updated appropriate custom fields to give extra permissions and assigned the correct role
      • Wrote a nightly job, scheduled to run a given time, that found expired certifications and removed permissions and roles that required an active certification
    • Wrote a display block that formatted the way courses within a learning path looked. This ensured that the information on the screen was easily understood, attractive and conformed to company standards

• Worked with a first-time Product Manager [PM], Customer Support, course specialists and QA to flesh out requirements and to update three separate back-end applications, thus improving the user experience and process flow for our video uploader, an IOS application.
    Goal: Make it so that creating and uploading videos with our IOS App integrates seamlessly with course assignments displayed in various applications.
    My responsibilities: Complete Analysis and any programming work in our backend applications
    The analysis and programming covered many languages, but the work detailed below only includes Totara tasks.
    • Worked with course specialists to agree upon terminology entered in specified fields when a course or assignment was added and to teach me how they set up a course. This helped me figure out what the PHP plugin code would look for, programmatically, in order to reply to a request sent by our IOS application
      • Needed to know how to recognize whether a given course and assignment within that course required the student to upload a video
      • Needed to know what age level, range of ages or if age was not relevant for the given course
        • Identification of Age Level or lack thereof
        • What colors to send to the IOS app to represent the given Ages
      • Learned how the course specialist entered the necessary pre-requisites for the given assignment. That information enabled the following:
        • Figured out how the assignment pre-requisites were stored in the database
        • Ensured that the student would not be able to upload a video until the assignment was visible in Totara and the student was ready
      • Understood where and how video would display in Totara once it was uploaded
  • Created a PHP Plugin to respond to the request that originated from the student's IOS application
    • Used many SQL queries to know what information, if any, to send to the IOS application
    • Using the criteria agreed upon with the course specialists, sent back the formatted information or a message indicating that no Totara applications were in the correct state for a student to upload a video
  • Created a PHP Plugin to receive the information that the IOS app sent back after the student created and uploaded a video. The Totara application needed to display the videos uploaded by the student in the following ways:
    • The student needed to play the video and to replace it, if desired
    • The student needed to be able to communicate information about the video
    • The teacher needed to play the video
    • The teacher needed to grade the assignment and write notes to the student

In my years of experience working with software development, one thing is always true. Developers that work as team, within a larger team, are stronger than individuals that work alone. The more people share information and discuss difficulties, the stronger everyone's work becomes.

The primary key to a high quality product and a happy workforce is open communication. As a developer, I listen to the testers, customer support and the product team and always help anyone who would benefit from my expertise. When I finish my sprint work early, I pick up tickets that other people can't get to. I communicate when my tickets are more complex than estimated, so everyone knows the possiblity that I may fall behind. If someone helps me, I give them credit and stand up for people who I feel are being overlooked or underestimated. These little day by day things do not show up in a resume, but make the entire organization stronger.

• Worked with a first-time Product Manager, Customer Support, course specialists and QA to flesh out complex requirements, write new Jira tickets and to update three unfamiliar, non-intuitive and complex back-end applications. The goal, to improve the user experience in our video upload mobile application, was fulfilled.
    Technologies: Ruby, Rails, Rest API, HTML5, MySQL, Totara, PHP
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• Satisfied angry and frustrated customers who were using an application with over 50 existing problems when another developer quit suddenly. Met with users individually and in small groups, organized and prioritized the problems, designed solutions and negotiated with management for additional programming resources. Resulted in a solid, usable system.
    Technologies: ACCESS, SQL Server, VB
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Led numerous projects as Team Lead (also acted as developer and system architect). Delivered all releases on time, meeting the requirements with very few bugs. This success was largely because of communication with people playing the following roles: people managers, project manager, specification writers, programmers, test lead, testers and the various platform owners.
    Technologies: Java, JavaScript, SQL Server, IDMS, Sybase, XML, XSLT, Web Services, SQL, ASP
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Worked with the Quality Director and Project Managers to design the Engineering Project Management processes that involved MS Project schedules and feasibility and status reporting. Upon review, the new processes were implemented with almost no changes.
    Technologies: VBA with MS Project
    Company: Medical Automation Systems (Abbott), Project Manager

• Learned MS Project and VBA independently, teaching the other engineering project managers enough MSP to get them over the initial learning curve. This enabled our engineering department to use MS Project in a consistent manner.
    Technologies:MS Project, VBA
    Company: Medical Automation Systems (Abbott), Project Manager

• Negotiated a reorganization of what was included in various related application releases, thus making our date independent of work done by other teams. Without the foresight to negotiate this change, we would not have released until the following year.
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Led six Print and CD (web application) releases: making all dates, and meeting all requirements. This success was based largely on communication, particularly listening to the development and the product management teams.
    Technologies: Java, JavaScript, SQL Server, IDMS, Sybase, SAS, XML, XSLT, Web Services, SQL, ASP, various middleware products
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Re-designed subscriptions statistics storage and reporting. Reports went from obscurity to being widely distributed, used and emulated.
    Technologies: SAS, IDMS
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Facilitated our best Indian contractor's move to the US to manage our off-shore resources and insure quality of our team's work.
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Frequently taken off of one project and assigned to a higher priority project. The transitions were seamless, because I had thoroughly documentated the processes.
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Developed a case law entry program, originally designed for limited usage, which was adopted and used company wide. Accomplished this by working with the law editors, who were our in-house customers and convincing my boss that it was needed.
    Technologies: VB, PL1
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Overhauled the trainer panel, turning a bug-laden application with inconsistent business rules into a serviceable application with consistent business rules. This was an interim solution, but workable enough to still be in place six years later.
    Technologies: PHP, jQuery, Ruby, Rails, Javascript, MySQL
    Company: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer

• Wrote programs that parsed and analyzed log files to monitor performance. Systematically eliminated pre-existing inefficiencies and bugs.
    Technologies: Java, JavaScript, XML, XSLT, SQL, ASP, HTML
    Company: LexisNexis, Senior Software Engineer

• Used data-driven test development. This allowed test data and creation data to be changed in one place, and made it easy to reuse assertion methods.
    Technologies: Ruby on Rails, Rspec, Python, Selenium, Pytest, MySql, SQL Server, Azure Pipeline
    Companies: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer; CoConstruct, QA Automation Engineer

• Set up a system that allowed many tests to be created quickly and ensured that the tests were both valuable to the business and followed object oriented and other best programming practices.
    Technologies: Python, Selenium, Pytest, SQL Server, Azure Pipelines
    Companies: Teachstone Training, Backend Web Developer; CoConstruct, QA Automation Engineer

• Eliminated login and navigation time by saving the login cookie and going directly to the page to be tested. Navigated to pages only when testing navigation.
    Technologies: Python, Selenium, Pytest, SQL Server, Azure Pipelines
    Company: CoConstruct, QA Automation Engineer

• Cached page data collected by screen scraping techniques, making it so the tests were comprehensive without the overhead of many page loads.
    Technologies: Python, Pytest, SQL Server, Azure Pipelines
    Company: CoConstruct, QA Automation Engineer

• As a first time Python user, set up a UI testing framework from scratch using Python, Pytest and Selenium.
    Technologies: Python, Selenium, Pytest, Azure Pipelines
    Company: CoConstruct, QA Automation Engineer

• Wrote, as a first year programmer, a dynamic menu program, in C++, which allocated and freed arrays of pointers without leaking any memory.
    Technologies: C++
Given these two images, what are they and which is native?

The one on the left is American Holly, based on the identification using PictureThis (IOS app), which may be wrong. Supposedly, English Hollies are difficult to distinguish from American Holly. English Ivy has glossier leaves, but that is subjective and otherwise the leaves are described almost identically. Because I can't be sure, I am assuming PictureThis is correct and the Hollies growing in my yard are American Holly, which is native to Eastern and Central US.
The one on the right is |beg|ilex-cornuta-chinese-holly-horned-holly|end|, definitely not native.
Image from |beg_ref|blueridgeprism_202008_factsheet_bradfordpear|end_ref|

paragraphs.subtitle: Callery Pear, early state
paragraphs.text: Bradford (Callery) Pear is native to China and Vietnam. It is beautiful, but also a particularly bad invasive in Virginia.
Focus on distinguishing characteristics and look-alikes. Image from |beg_ref|blueridgeprism_201706_factsheet_japanesestiltgrass|end_ref|.

Japanese Stiltgrass is one of the biggest problem invasives in the Charlottesville area. Often I see this when I walk in the woods. Japanese stilt grass is really easy to pull, but there's just so much of it.

It's main distinguishing characteristic is it has a silvery middle vein and has alternate leaf blades. Once I pulled up an |beg|immature-solidago-caesia-bluestem-goldenrod|end|, thinking it was stilt grass.
